Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Comparative ontogeny: dinosaur growth, development, and intraspecific variation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Shifts in metabolic rates often accompany major evolutionary transitions in organismal function and ecology. Examples include the evolution of endothermy (warm-bloodedness) and elevated metabolism in archosaurs (birds and their close relatives, ~12,000 species) and mammals (~5,000 species). High metabolic rates are thought to be a key component of mammalian and archosaur species radiations, by allowing individuals to exploit a wider range of environmental and temporal niches (lifestyles). For their body size, extant birds have some of the highest growth rates and metabolisms of any vertebrates. High avian metabolic rates are also associated with highly canalized development, as seen in the relative lack of body size variation for individuals of a given age. The primary aim of this research is to understand how these extreme physiological and developmental specializations arose within the dinosaur ancestors of birds. This project will produce two major broader impacts. First, data and interpretations generated by this project will be incorporated into updates to an exhibit currently in development at the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), ?Dinosaurs Among Us.? This exhibit is a multi-media showcase of the various lines of evidence supporting the hypothesis that birds evolved from non-avian dinosaurs. It uses fossil specimens, models, graphics, and interactives to reveal the latest findings about the dinosaurian origins of many typically avian traits. The PIs are actively involved in consulting on the scientific content of the exhibit, which, together with associated museum events and an extensive online presence, will reach a large portion of the 5 million annual visitors to AMNH and many others globally. Educational materials from the exhibit will reach a diverse group of students, many from underserved communities in New York City. Second, this project greatly enhances the infrastructure of the AMNH paleontology laboratory to conduct histological research on fossil tissues. Training in histological techniques will enable the PIs to further train AMNH staff and students, developing the human resources of the laboratory to support projects involving histological analysis for years to come.

Calculation of dinosaur growth rates (a proxy for metabolism) from their bone microstructure has demonstrated that the transition to modern avian endothermy did not occur in a single step. The earliest birds, for example, grew more rapidly than non-avian reptiles, but more slowly than their extant descendants. However, the origin of elevated metabolic rates among the earliest theropod dinosaur ancestors of birds remains unknown. This project seeks to fill this gap in knowledge, by using bone histology (examination of the microscopic organization of bone tissue) and gross morphology to measure growth rate and ontogenetic canalization for a phylogenetically basal theropod dinosaur, Coelophysis bauri. As it is one of the only extinct dinosaurs with a large sample size (hundreds of specimens) available from single populations, histological sectioning and growth curve construction for Coelophysis bauri will shed light on the metabolic condition of some of the earliest diverging theropod dinosaurs, and provide a framework within which the transition to rapid growth rates and developmental canalization among bird-line archosaurs may be assessed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project enhanced the successfully defended dissertation research of the co-PI, Daniel Barta, by allowing him to construct one of the largest bone microstructure datasets for a carnivorous dinosaur to date. These data reveal that growth among a population of the 200-million year-old Coelophysis bauri, one of the earliest members of the dinosaur group (theropods) that includes birds, was highly variable, with little correlation between age and size increase. Furthermore, these data were combined with observations of muscle scars and bone fusions to show that such features, previously held as indicators of maturity, are also poorly correlated with age. Despite this more reptilian style of highly variable growth, bone tissue organization indicates that growth rates were higher than that of living reptiles. Collectively, these findings suggest that early dinosaurs such as Coelophysisoccupied a transitional state between reptilian- and avian-style growth, which may imply a metabolic rate intermediate between that of living “cold-blooded” reptiles and “warm-blooded” birds.

            Broadly, this project contributes to comparative studies of dinosaur growth in a larger biological context and enhances knowledge of individual, growth-related, and evolutionary variability in vertebrate (backboned animal) bone tissues. Through this research, the PIs greatly augmented the capabilities of the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) paleontology laboratory to conduct histological studies on fossils. The histology equipment purchased and training of laboratory staff and students in paleohistological techniques will enrich the research capabilities of the AMNH Division of Paleontology for years to come.

            This research promoted public understanding of science through Daniel Barta’s frequent talks and media outreach activities, including videos on the AMNH website and associated social media accounts, which collectively reach millions of unique visitors and followers. Through the AMNH Lang Science Program, Daniel Barta created classroom activities for high school students that guided them to discover the latest findings in bone histology and other dinosaur biology research, encouraging a deeper understanding of the process of scientific inquiry. The PIs also anticipate that this research will be incorporated into future updates of the “Dinosaurs Among Us” portion of the Center for Science and Industry’s (Columbus, Ohio) Dinosaur Gallery, produced in partnership with AMNH. The initial run of “Dinosaurs Among Us” at AMNH, for which the PIs advised on scientific content, reached over 380,000 visitors.

            Research results from collections travel supported by this project have been distributed to the scientific community in the open access article “The evolution of the manus of early theropod dinosaurs is characterized by high inter- and intraspecific variation,” published in Journal of Anatomy. This article presents the first evidence of high levels of anatomical variation in the hand and wrist anatomy of early dinosaurs, including Coelophysis. This provides an exceptionally detailed view into the initial appearance of new hand and wrist characters within members of a fossil population, revealing the earliest stages of modification that eventually produced the highly modified avian hand and wrist. Further, this grant allowed Daniel Barta to present his dissertation results on the skeletal development of modern birds at the 9thInternational Meeting of the Society of Avian Paleontology and Evolution. Results of the Coelophysis histology project will be presented to the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology meeting in October 2018. The PIs are currently preparing additional scientific papers expounding further upon this research.
